Bar Series View source

The bar series renders the given data as a series of vertical bars:

var dataGenerator = fc.data.random.walk();
var data = dataGenerator(20).map(function(datum, index) {
    return {
        x: index,
        y: datum
    };
});

var xScale = d3.scale.linear()
    .domain(fc.util.extent().pad(0.1).fields(['x'])(data))
    .range([0, width]);

var yScale = d3.scale.linear()
    .domain(fc.util.extent().fields(['y'])(data))
    .range([height, 0]);

var bar = fc.series.bar()
    .xValue(function(d) { return d.x; })
    .yValue(function(d) { return d.y; })
    .xScale(xScale)
    .yScale(yScale);

container.append('g')
    .datum(data)
    .call(bar);

Which gives the following:

This series has the same xValue, yValue and decorate properties as the point series. You can also specify the width of the bars via the barWidth property.

The bar series supports horizonal display, using the orient property.

var dataGenerator = fc.data.random.walk();
var data = dataGenerator(20).map(function(datum, index) {
    return {
        // notice that x & y have been transposed!
        x: datum,
        y: index
    };
});

var xScale = d3.scale.linear()
    .domain(fc.util.extent().fields(['x'])(data))
    .range([0, width]);

var yScale = d3.scale.linear()
    .domain(fc.util.extent().fields(['y'])(data))
    .range([height, 0]);

var bar = fc.series.bar()
    .xValue(function(d) { return d.x; })
    .yValue(function(d) { return d.y; })
    .xScale(xScale)
    .yScale(yScale)
    .orient('horizontal');

container.append('g')
    .datum(data)
    .call(bar);

Which gives the following:
